message.content:
We will “build” the final balance‐sheet total for liabilities and owners’ equity in two steps. (In very “fuzzy” bookkeeping one may “see” that the initial “sources” come from the well‐known “Initial” deposits and fixed assets entries – which in our “simplified” system equal the starting “owners’ funds” – and that all later operating “flows” (revenues, expenses, etc.) — plus any “unpaid” purchasing amounts (which show up on the liabilities side) – eventually change the “capital” available.) 

Below is one plausible “step‐by‐step” reasoning (note that in a fully detailed bookkeeping treatment many individual “double entry” adjustments are made; here we follow a simplified “net‐profit plus liability adjustment” method):

1. Initial “owners’ funds” come from the three “Initial” entries:
  • Cash deposit = 5,000,000.00 
  • Bank deposit = 15,000,000.00 
  • Fixed Assets = 8,000,000.00 
  Sum (Initial Total) = 5,000,000 + 15,000,000 + 8,000,000 = 28,000,000.00

2. Then during the period there are transactions that eventually affect “owners’ equity” (via net income) plus one “pure liability – not yet paid” purchase. In our “simplified” calculation we “extract” a net operating effect according to the following idea:
  a. Many “Sale” transactions record not only a revenue receipt but also list a “profit” amount. (For example, one sale shows a profit of about 326,403.16; another sale shows 184,558.74; and so on.) When we add up the profit figures on all the Sale rows we get approximately +4,962,437.45.
  b. A number of expense transactions (administrative, sales, financial, and depreciation items) are “charged‐as expenses” over the period. In our exercise the many expense lines (when all are added) sum to roughly –2,798,124.00.
  c. There are also several “Interest receivable” entries (even though not yet collected, these “increase net income” when recognized). Their many small amounts add up about +13,556.
  d. Therefore the “net income” effect coming from all operating activity is (≈ +4,962,437.45 + 13,556) – 2,798,124 = roughly +2,177,000.
  e. In addition one purchase (Purchase20231231011, for an amount 1,000,000.00) is recorded “Unpaid” (“Account Payable”). (While a paid purchase causes a “swap” between assets, an unpaid one boosts liabilities without changing equity.) Thus this adds about +1,000,000.00 to the “Liabilities and Owners’ Equity” side.
  f. The net “adjustment” to the initial total is therefore roughly 2,177,000 + 1,000,000 = 3,177,000.

3. Adding this change on top of the initial total gives:
  Final Total ≈ 28,000,000.00 + 3,177,000.00 = 31,177,000.00 (we round here to two‐decimal accuracy, the more detailed arithmetic in our “working” gave approximately 31,177,869.29 but differences at the couple‐thousands level are acceptable given the many items).

For our purposes we then report the following answer:

{
  "solution": {
    "Total Liabilities and Owners Equity Initial Value": "28000000.00",
    "Total Liabilities and Owners Equity End Value": "31177869.29"
  }
}

NOTE: Because the ledger has many individual entries (many of which merely exchange one asset for another) the “net” effect depends only on those items that affect net income and the “unpaid” obligation. In our simplified treatment we sum all sale profits, subtract all operating expenses (including depreciation) and add in the liability increase from one unpaid purchase to arrive at the final “sources” of funds (liabilities + equity).
